text: Parliamentary elections were held in Laos on 18 July 1965.Dieter Nohlen, Florian Grotz & Christof Hartmann (2001) Elections in Asia: A data handbook, Volume II, p135 The elections were boycotted by the Lao Patriotic Front,Haruhiro Fukui (1985) Political parties of Asia and the Pacific, Greenwood Press, pp689–690 and saw the Southern Bloc emerge as the largest party with 15 of the 59 seats.Nohlen et al., p138 However, only 22,000 citizens were allowed to vote, with the franchise restricted to politicians, civil servants, army officers, police and local government officers.Dieter Nohlen, Florian Grotz & Christof Hartmann (2001) Elections in Asia: A data handbook, Volume II, p133 ==Results== {| class=wikitable style=text- align:right !Party !Votes !% !Seats |- |align=left|Southern Bloc|| || ||15 |- |align=left|Lao Neutralist Party|| || ||14 |- |align=left|Youth Movement|| || ||12 |- |align=left|Vientiane Group|| || ||9 |- |align=left|Independents|| || ||9 |- |align=left|Invalid/blank votes|| ||–||– |- |align=left|Total|| || ||59 |- |colspan=5 align=left|Source: Nohlen et al. |} ==References== Category:1965 elections in Asia Category:Elections in Laos Category:1965 in Laos
title: 1965 Laotian parliamentary election
